dhp209-220:209: Giving himself to things to be shunned and not exerting where exertion is needed, a seeker after pleasures, having given up his true welfare, envies those intent upon theirs.
dhp209-220:210: Seek no intimacy with the beloved and also not with the unloved, for not to see the beloved and to see the unloved, both are painful.
dhp209-220:211: Therefore hold nothing dear, for separation from the dear is painful. There are no bonds for those who have nothing beloved or unloved.
dhp209-220:212: From endearment springs grief, from endearment springs fear. For one who is wholly free from endearment there is no grief, whence then fear?
dhp209-220:213: From affection springs grief, from affection springs fear. For one who is wholly free from affection there is no grief, whence then fear?
dhp209-220:214: From attachment springs grief, from attachment springs fear. For one who is wholly free from attachment there is no grief, whence then fear?
dhp209-220:215: From lust springs grief, from lust springs fear. For one who is wholly free from craving there is no grief; whence then fear?
dhp209-220:216: From craving springs grief, from craving springs fear. For one who is wholly free from craving there is no grief; whence then fear?
dhp209-220:217: People hold dear him who embodies virtue and insight, who is principled, has realized the truth, and who himself does what he ought to be doing.
dhp209-220:218: One who is intent upon the Ineffable (Nibbāna), dwells with mind inspired (by supramundane wisdom), and is no more bound by sense pleasures—such a man is called "One Bound Upstream."
dhp209-220:219: When, after a long absence, a man safely returns from afar, his relatives, friends and well-wishers welcome him home on arrival.
dhp209-220:220: As kinsmen welcome a dear one on arrival, even so his own good deeds will welcome the doer of good who has gone from this world to the next.
